trial_identification.studytitle: A randomised controlled trial of fish oil for treatment of aggressive behaviour in young people
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised controlled trial of fish oil capsules compared to placebo capsules for the treatment of overt aggression in children and adolescents with disruptive behaviour disorders

conditions.healthcondition: Overt aggression associated with disruptive behaviour disorders

interventions.interventions: Fish oil oral capsules - 4 grams fish oil daily, containing a total of 400mg Eicosapentaenoic Acid (EPA) and 2000mg Docosahexaenoic Acid (DHA), for 6 weeks continuous treatment
interventions.comparator: Identical placebo capsules (4 grams low polyphenol olive oil daily, with trace amounts of fish oil to mask taste, oral capsules for 6 weeks continuous treatment)

primaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and at 6 and 12 weeks after commencement of intervention

primaryOutcome.outcome: Overt aggressive behaviour (Modified Overt Aggression Scale)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and weekly for 12 weeks after commencement of intervention

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and at 6 and 12 weeks after commencement of intervention

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1. Presence of overt aggressive behaviours 2. Diagnosis of one of the disruptive behaviour disorders (Oppositional Defiant Disorder or Conduct Disorder) 3. Under 18 years of age
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. Over 17 years of age 2. Diagnosis of any of the following: autism or other developmental disorder; mental retardation; schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder or substance use disorder

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Aggressive behaviours are common issues in young people accessing mental health services. Fish oils are popular treatments and are sometimes marketed for behavioural problems. However, no research has specifically examined fish oils for aggressive behaviour in young people. This study will examine whether fish oil is able to reduce the frequency and severity of aggressive behaviour in children and adolescents.
